key_insight: A generative neural stochastic differential equation (neural SDE) framework that learns state-dependent drift and diffusion lets you accurately model and simulate cell-state dynamics, including variability and responses to perturbations.
problem_solved: Captures complex, stochastic, state-dependent temporal behavior of cells (including heterogeneity and noise) and enables counterfactual/perturbation simulations that existing deterministic or static models cannot reliably produce.
method: Formulate cell dynamics as a neural stochastic differential equation and parametrize both drift and diffusion as neural networks (state-dependent noise).
Train the generative model to match observed single‑cell trajectories/distributions, enabling sampling of realistic stochastic trajectories.
Use the learned SDE to simulate counterfactual perturbations and compare/validate against experimental data, demonstrating improved fidelity over prior methods.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a principled, scalable way to model noisy dynamical systems and run simulated interventions — valuable for single‑cell analysis, experiment planning, and any domain with state-dependent stochastic dynamics.
visual_elements: Schematic of a neural SDE: input cell state → neural drift and diffusion nets → stochastic trajectory sampler
Trajectory comparison plot (real vs. simulated) on a low‑dimensional embedding (UMAP/t‑SNE) showing overlapping paths and variability
Vector field / heatmap illustrating state‑dependent drift and diffusion magnitude across cell states
Perturbation experiment panel: baseline trajectory vs. simulated perturbed trajectory with predicted outcome metrics
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
